did.head: Overview of the Collection

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Archives & Special Collections at the Thomas J. Dodd Center

did.abstract: The Daniel Yankelovich Papers document the career of a noted scholar, social researcher and public opinion analyst from roughly 1955 to 1994.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Daniel Yankelovich, noted social researcher and public opinion analyst, was born in 1924 in Boston, Massachusetts. He earned both his bachelor's degree (1946) and M.A.(1950) from Harvard University. Post-graduate studies at the Sorbonne in Paris led Yankelovich to embark upon an academic career. He also holds honorary doctorates from Washington University and George Washington University largely for his work in the public sector.

Yankelovich taught as a Research Professor of Psychology at New York University (1968-1973) and a Professor of Psychology in the Graduate Faculty of the New School for Social Research (1973-1978). In 1981 the University of California at Irvine named him a Distinguished Scholar. In 1996 Yankelovich served as a Senior Fellow at the Harvard University Kennedy School of Government and currently lectures as a Visiting Professor at the University of California at San Diego.

In 1958 Yankelovich temporarily departed academia to found the marketing and research firm Daniel Yankelovich, Inc., which was renamed in 1974 to Yankelovich, Skelly, & White, Inc. He chaired this company from 1958-1986. In 1976, joining former U.S. Secretary of State Cyrus Vance, he founded the Public Agenda Foundation, a nonprofit organization intended "to find and test new ways to present complex public issues." Yankelovich subsequently created the New York Times/Yankelovich Poll in the mid-1970s, which evolved into the New York Times/CBS Poll. He serves as the chairman of DYG, Inc. which he established in 1986. Yankelovich has held directorships at firms such as CBS, Inc., Loral Corporation, Meredith Corporation, Reliance Group Holdings and U.S. West, Inc., among others. He has served as a trustee at the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Education, the Charles F. Kettering Foundation, Brown University, and other institutions and organizations.

Mr. Yankelovich has authored nine books in addition to hundreds of speeches and articles. His books include, Beyond the Beltway: Engaging the Public in U.S. Foreign Policy (1994), Coming to Public Judgment: Making Democracy Work in a Complex World (1991), Starting with the People (1988), New Rules: Searching for Self-fulfillment in a World Turned Upside Down (1981), and Ego and Instinct: The Psychoanalytic View of Human Nature-Revised (1969).

Mr. Yankelovich has a daughter, Nicole, through his first marriage to Hassie Kaboolian. In 1991 he wed Mary Komarnicki, who also worked in the social research/public opinion field after earning a master's degree in Social Ecology from St. Bonaventure University in 1983.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Daniel Yankelovich Papers document the career of a noted scholar, social researcher and public opinion analyst from roughly 1955 to 1994. The collection consists primarily of research and draft material for three books, Coming to Public Judgment: Making Democracy Work in a Complex World (1991), Starting with the People (1988), New Rules: Searching for Self-fulfillment in a World Turned Upside Down (1981), and numerous survey projects, such as "The Public, the Soviets, and Nuclear Arms". Although the majority of the public opinion material covers political life, a wide variety social issues receive attention as well. The papers also chronicle Yankelovich's participation in numerous organizations and the involvement of his second wife, Mary Komarnicki Yankelovich, in public opinion analysis.

arrangement.head: Organization
arrangement.p: Series I: Writings (1947-1992) houses the various writings and related materials of Yankelovich. The series has been broken down into the following subseries: Articles, Books, Other Writings, and Presentations. The Articles subseries contains copies of a number of Yankelovich's many newspaper and journal articles. In some cases there is additional material, such as notes or fan mail. The Books subseries includes varying amounts of r esearch material, drafts, reviews, and miscellaneous material for the three books Coming to Public Judgment: Making Democracy Work in a Complex World (1991), New Rules: Searching for Self-fulfillment in a World Turned Upside Down (1981), and Starting with the People (1988). Interviews for the New Rules book have been restricted until 1/1/ 2009. The material for each book has been typically arranged in order of creation. Documents from the Abrams Lecture Series and the New Framework Group are in this subseries because of their relation to the books. The Other Writings subseries contains copies of odd materials such as reports and book chapters. The Presentations subseries encompasses material associated with the many speeches, discussions, and conference presentations given by Yankelovich. Not all folders contain copies of the presentation text.

Series II: Projects (1949-1994) showcases the materials associated with several major survey projects. The series is broken down into several broad subject categories, such as, Harvard Business Review Projects, Nuclear Policy Projects, Work Projects, and Youth Projects. Each of these subseries embody several projects with the materials for each endeavor arranged in order of creation.

Series III: Organizations/Professional Services (1960-1992) includes any material associated with Yankelovich's professional presence in organizations such as the Carnegie Foundation, the National Science Foundation, Public Agenda Foundation, and firms such as Yankelovich, Skelly, & White, Inc. and WSY Consulting Group. For the most part, the materials include meeting agenda books and reports, but in some cases include a wider range of documents. The series is arranged alphabetically by institution name.

Series IV: Subject Files (1965- 1992) contains source material associated with subjects of interest to Yankelovich, such as education, politics and government, and polls. The documents consist primarily of books, reports, and papers. A collection of Harris Surveys and Business Week/Harris Polls from 1975- 1988 (with some gaps) may prove of particular interest to researchers. The series is arranged alphabetically by subject.

Series V: Related Material (1959-1991) encompasses a wide range of papers not related directly with the material in the other series. For example, there are miscellaneous books and journals, interviews with Yankelovich, two television series proposals, material dealing with Mr. Yankelovich's involvement at New York University, and personal papers. A clippings scrapbook covering the period from 1959-1969 comprises one highlight of this series. The series is arranged alphabetically by general subject headings.

Series VI: Mary Komarnicki Yankelovich (1937-1993) holds the material created by or belonging to Mary Komarnicki. The series is subdivided into Projects and Related Material subseries. The Projects subseries contains additional material pertaining to Coming to Public Judgment: Making Democracy work in a Complex World and the GlobeTrends 1990 project.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Archives & Special Collections has a substantial collection of public polling materials. See especially the papers of Elmo Roper, Samuel Lubell, James M. Vicary, and Archibald Crossley. For detailed information on these collections please contact the curator or ask at the reference desk.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: In order to maintain the confidentiality of the interviewees, the interviews used for the writing of New Rules: Searching for Self-Fulfillment in a World Turned Upside Down (1981) will be restricted until January 1, 2009.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Permission to publish from these Papers must be obtained in writing from both the University of Connecticut Libraries and the owner(s) of the copyright. Mr. Yankelovich retains the copyright on the papers.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item, Folder #]. Daniel Yankelovich Papers. Archives & Special Collections at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center, University of Connecticut Libraries.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The Daniel Yankelovich Papers were donated to the University of Connecticut by Mr. Yankelovich in October of 1995.
